Article
Full-text available

  • Rafael Bañón
  • Toño Maño
  • Gonzalo Mucientes
The anomalous presence of numerous blue shark Prionace glauca neonates and juveniles in shallow inshore waters of Galicia, north-west Spain, during the summers of 2014 and 2015 is reported. Changes in oceanographic conditions, high recruitment events or changes in the pupping area are discussed as possible causes of this unusual behaviour.

Projects

Projects (9)
DEEP-PATH The Path to the Deep Sea. Genomic adaptations of marine fishes to deep waters.
Project
To study how marine fishes adapt to deep waters by NGS DNA and RNA analyses. By comparative analyses in two different marine fish taxa (genus Gaidropsarus and order Notacanthiformes), identify functional modifications in key gene groups related to adaptation to deep sea, evolutionary convergence events, and newly developed adaptations compared with phylogenetic inheritance. The new data obtained will be useful to estimate the potential adaptation to marine fish species to deeper waters, helping to stablish proper conservation and management politicies.
View
Invasive Alien Species
Project
View
SP-PORC-Q3: Spanish Bottom Trawl Survey on the Porcupine Bank
Project
The Spanish Bottom Trawl Survey on the Porcupine Bank (ICES Divisions 7.c and 7.k) has been carried out annually since 2001 by the Spanish Institute of Oceanography (IEO). Its aim is to collect data on the distribution and relative abundance, and biological information of demersal fish species and invertebrates with particular emphasis on commercial species exploited by the Spanish fleet, such as hake, monkfish, white anglerfish and megrim.
